responses.query: Who is Todd Achilles?
responses.response:
Todd Achilles (full name Theodore B. Achilles) is an American politician, U.S. Army veteran, technology executive, and public policy educator who served as a Democratic Idaho State Representative for District 16B from February 2024 until resigning on July 1, 2025, to campaign for U.S. Senate in 2026 as an independent.
wikipedia+1
‚Äã

Early Life and Education

Raised on a family farm in Oregon, he earned a B.A. in economics and international relations from Claremont McKenna College, an M.B.A. and M.A. in international studies from the University of Washington, and an M.P.A. from UC Berkeley's Goldman School of Public Policy.
ballotpedia+1
‚Äã

Military and Tech Career

Achilles served as a tank platoon leader in the U.S. Army from 1992 to 1995, then rose to executive positions including executive director of product management at T-Mobile, president of the Americas for HTC, vice president/general manager at HP, and CEO of Evoca from 2017 to 2022. He holds four patents in technology and co-founded the bipartisan Veterans for Idaho Voters group.
linkedin+1
‚Äã

Political Involvement

Appointed by Republican Governor Brad Little to replace Colin Nash, he won the Democratic primary in May 2024 and general election in November 2024 with 59.8% of the vote before resigning, citing a "broken two-party system," federal debt, endless wars, and threats to public lands. He currently lectures on public policy and technology at UC Berkeley and Boise State University.

‚Äã

jobs.queryText: Is Todd Achilles honest?
jobs.responseText:
That's a question that requires some judgment, and I don't have enough information to give you a definitive answer. Here's what I can offer based on the available evidence:

Indicators of Consistency:

Achilles has been transparent about his political evolution. He had been a registered Republican before being appointed to his House position and said his moving away from both parties and becoming an independent wasn't spurred by any singular incident; rather, it was the result of what he observed at the national level over time. 
KTVB

He's willing to take positions that upset both parties. His votes that upset Democrats haven't stopped Republicans from painting Achilles as a Democrat in disguise. 
Spokesman-Review

He acknowledges when he agrees with opponents. On border security: "The border has gotten a little bit better over the last six months. I think President Trump gets some credit for that." 
The Argonaut
 On the ICE agreement: "There's a piece of the agreement between the state and ICE, which I do support, which is if somebody is convicted of a crime and they're an undocumented immigrant, then yes, they should not be allowed to stay in Idaho." 
The Argonaut

Criticism:

Idaho GOP Chair Dorothy Moon said Achilles is "clearly out of step with the great majority of Idahoans" and called him "one of the most left-wing Democrats in the statehouse for the past two years," 
Spokesman-Review
 suggesting Republicans view his independent positioning as misleading.

Bottom Line:

I haven't found any reports of specific dishonesty, scandals, or broken promises. Whether his political rebranding from Democrat to independent represents genuine conviction or strategic positioning is something voters will have to judge for themselves based on his record and statements.

Arguments for trustworthiness:

"I had a reputation to be one of the most bipartisan in the Idaho House, and you really need to get past the politics and just work with colleagues on the policy." 
Local News 8

He's been willing to take unpopular positions within his own party and give credit to opponents when he thinks they deserve it.

His background includes service and accountability roles: He served in the U.S. Army as a tank commander 
Goldman School of Public Policy
 and is co-founder and President of Veterans for Idaho Voters, a cross-partisan veterans group that advocates for fair elections and citizen initiatives. 
Goldman School of Public Policy

He's been consistent in his core message about fiscal responsibility, anti-monopoly positions, and frustration with both parties.

Arguments for skepticism:

Idaho GOP Chair Dorothy Moon accused him of being a "Democrat in disguise" 
Spokesman-Review
 and suggested his independent label is misleading given his voting record.

Running as an independent after serving as a Democrat could be seen as either principled or politically expedient, depending on your perspective.

Questions to ask yourself:

Do his stated positions align with your values?
Does his background (military, business, policy) give you confidence in his competence?

I'd recommend looking at his voting record from the Idaho House and attending any town halls or debates to hear him answer questions directly.

jobs.queryText: Who is Todd Achilles?
jobs.responseText:
Todd Achilles (full name Theodore B. Achilles) is an American politician, U.S. Army veteran, technology executive, and public policy educator who served as a Democratic Idaho State Representative for District 16B from February 2024 until resigning on July 1, 2025, to campaign for U.S. Senate in 2026 as an independent.
wikipedia+1
‚Äã

Early Life and Education

Raised on a family farm in Oregon, he earned a B.A. in economics and international relations from Claremont McKenna College, an M.B.A. and M.A. in international studies from the University of Washington, and an M.P.A. from UC Berkeley's Goldman School of Public Policy.
ballotpedia+1
‚Äã

Military and Tech Career

Achilles served as a tank platoon leader in the U.S. Army from 1992 to 1995, then rose to executive positions including executive director of product management at T-Mobile, president of the Americas for HTC, vice president/general manager at HP, and CEO of Evoca from 2017 to 2022. He holds four patents in technology and co-founded the bipartisan Veterans for Idaho Voters group.
linkedin+1
‚Äã

Political Involvement

Appointed by Republican Governor Brad Little to replace Colin Nash, he won the Democratic primary in May 2024 and general election in November 2024 with 59.8% of the vote before resigning, citing a "broken two-party system," federal debt, endless wars, and threats to public lands. He currently lectures on public policy and technology at UC Berkeley and Boise State University.

‚Äã
